body: Cookies and local storage _should_ roam across users

@paulcbetts you may be right, that's sounds the most logical thing to do.

But Chrome store all Browser data in LOCALAPPDATA. I don't know why.
Maybe a compatibility purpose or because they want to handle roam on their own.

Well in anycase, this issue is still valid for cache data (http cache and GPUCache)
Using `%LOCALAPPDATA%` for cache dir sounds good to me, but Chrome would still store cache in `%APPDATA%` as far as I know.

@zcbenz on windows Google Chrome store cache AND user data in `%LOCALAPPDATA%`
And more precisely in `%LOCALAPPDATA%\Google\Chrome\User Data`.
Google chrome does not use `%APPDATA%`.
https://productforums.google.com/forum/#!topic/chrome/keN3Njx6gtM

**But** `%LOCALAPPDATA%` have been introduced in windows 7. Previous version of windows does not have this environnement variables set nor the corresponding path. %APPDATA% is a fallback path on Vista and XP.

So cache path should be set to

``` javascript
process.env.LOCALAPPDATA || process.env.APPDATA
```

Dropbox recently updated their app to prefer LOCALAPPDATA over APPDATA (which roams).

Often the app data is too large to roam, i.e. it's not just cookies.

> Previous version of windows does not have this environnement variables set nor the corresponding path

Atom Shell doesn't run on XP or Vista anyways, we don't have to worry about that

I'm not particularly excited about this change, I think we should close it. This is causing a problem for exactly zero users right now, but moving it has the potential to break everyone currently using Atom Shell who don't write a carefully coded migration routine, and end up breaking users. Zero benefit, non-zero downside == wontfix

Chromium doesn't actually make use of the `cache` dir for browser's cache data, all cookies and caches are stored under `appData` dir. So making `cache` dir default to `%LOCALAPPDATA%` affects nothing unless user explicitly relies on the location of `cache` dir, but it also means it won't do what you wanted, e.g. move browser cache files to `%LOCALAPPDATA%`.

@zcbenz from my tests and from chromium documentation, Chromium uses the same paths than Chrome except it replaces `Google/Chrome` by `Chromium`: All in `%LOCALAPPDATA%`, nothing in `%APPDATA%`
https://www.chromium.org/user-experience/user-data-directory

Reminder: 
`%LOCALAPPDATA%` => `HOME/Appdata/Local/`
`%APPDATA%` => `HOME/Appdata/Roaming/`

> This is causing a problem for exactly zero users right now

The atom folder is getting bigger and bigger and in our company "Roaming" is synced on every windows login/logoff. When using plugins you get tens of thousand node_module files that slow down the syncing process.
@bux578 The ~/.atom folder or node_modules isn't stored in AppData, you should file an issue about this in Atom

After a closer looking, I found that Chromium doesn't respect the `cache` directory at all in most places, for things like browser caches and GPU caches the path is hard-coded under `userData` and there is no way to change that. So I'm going to remove the `cache` path since it is useless and causes many confusions.
+1 for @etiktin solution

I think the root problem is we don't separate users data from cache in Electron, if we keep user data like LocalStorage and Cookie in `%APPDATA%`, and then make `cache` dir work and move cache data to `% LOCALAPPDATA%`, everything should work fine?

We don't know how much data each application uses. For example see #2903 where the user is talking about having more than 500 MB of data (indexedDB + WebSQL). I'm not saying that's the general case, but it can happen. `%LOCALAPPDATA%` seems like a safer default and that's probably why Chrome and Chromium use it. 

There's a similar discussion about npm [here](https://github.com/npm/npm/issues/4564) (including some examples about the issues that arise from using roaming in an enterprise environment).

`%LOCALAPPDATA%` is a suitable choice for Chrome because it has no idea of how much data the third party websites would use, and it is safe to assume websites only use localStorage for cache.

But in Electron the app author is in charge of everything, and under most cases the data written to localStorage are user preferences. Though we don't know how much data the apps would use, but the app authors do, so if they just want to put 500MB of data into `%APPDATA%` we should not prevent them.

The good thing of keeping localStorage in `%APPDATA%` is we don't need to change behavior of current apps, and app data get roaming by default.

I agree with @etiktin and his proposal would solve the issue neatly for everyone.

I know Dropbox recently moved their storage from `roaming` to `local` probably for the same reason.

Apps should only use `roaming` if they opt-in to it and know what they are doing. It should not be the default.

Another problem is Squirrel, the popular Windows installer used by Electron apps, is installing the app into `%LOCALAPPDATA%`, so if we store user data under `%LOCALAPPDATA%` we are going to face file conflicts someday.

If we make the change (moving both cache and userData or just cache), we can fix the paths so conflicts won't occur. For example:

```
// Electron folders
%LOCALAPPDATA%\MyApp\Cache
%LOCALAPPDATA%\MyApp\UserData // Will hold the Local Storage, Cookies etc.

// Squirrel folders
%LOCALAPPDATA%\MyApp\app-1.0.15
%LOCALAPPDATA%\MyApp\app-1.0.16
%LOCALAPPDATA%\MyApp\Bin
...
```

This is a huge problem for Squirrel apps if you decide to do this, because Squirrel will wipe this directory under certain circumstances (uninstall, clean install) and we will lose user data. Not to mention, this will break existing apps. 

I'm very much not excited about this change - I don't care _at all_ that what we're doing now is technically wrong, and while I have some sympathy for the roaming profiles scenario, I don't think it warrants breaking software to do it.

It was just an example. If that's problematic we can put it under a different path.

```
%LOCALAPPDATA%\MyApp // Squirrel
%LOCALAPPDATA%\MyAppData // Will contain cache and userData
```

Like I said in my previous [comment](https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/1404#issuecomment-145384253), it's possible to do this without breaking anything and if we choose to move both cache and userData it will be a really simple fix.

The reason to do it, is to prevent weird issues and customer complaints by enterprise customers, which are pretty much the only folks that can "enjoy" roaming to begin with. If someone really needs roaming, they can opt-in and set the path to `%APPDATA%` and by doing that they now what they are getting into.
IMO It will be easier to make the change now than later.

> The reason to do it, is to prevent weird issues and customer complaints by enterprise customers, which are pretty much the only folks that can "enjoy" roaming to begin with

Can you provide any concrete examples? We ship the most deployed enterprise Electron Windows app in the world at Slack, and I haven't heard anyone complain about this

I think we're mixing up `User documents` with `App data & settings` into `User data`.
There is no reason for storing `User documents` into thoose wierd directories, most apps will propose to strore it into user  `Home` or `My documents`

So we're talking about `App data & settings`

@paulcbetts 
As a user, I expect `App data & settings` to be removed on uninstall or clean install. There are very few exception where thoose should be kept on uninstall. And in thoose rare cases, this is the responsability of the developers to explicitly store thoose important settings in roaming instead of localstorage (which is an ephemeral location by definition)
So, I don't think Squirrel wiping this dir on uninstall is a problem, this is the wanted behavior and it should be the default.

So I find the first proposition of @etiktin a good solution: it also fix the issue of most installers that does not remove cache and settings when uninstalling.

Then to avoid breaking changes, the best way is probably to test if old path exists and use it in this case.

> As a user, I expect App data & settings to be removed on uninstall or clean install. There are very few exception where those should be kept on uninstall.

This is explicitly _not_ the policy of how Squirrel works - developers can _choose_ to do this, but Squirrel won't do it by default. You are changing that policy for Electron apps with this change.

Cleaning up after uninstall, is not related to this proposal, so I rater not get into that.

Let's say I have an app called ACME and I'm using it on my company laptop. I also have a desktop which I use from time to time. I left ACME open on my laptop and started working on my PC where I also open ACME. I do a bunch of stuff there that modify userData (Local Storage, indexedDB etc.) and then I close it. The data is supposed to be synced, but I won't actually see it. Once I close ACME on my laptop the data will be rewritten so the sync disappears. When I open ACME again on the desktop, it's userData would change to the data from the laptop. I lost what ever I stored in Local Storage.

The point of this contrived story, is that roaming doesn't really work for Electron (and of course Chrome/Chromium). If you really want to sync settings/configuration you should implement that yourself. If we would have used `%LOCALAPPDATA%` the results would have been different. Each instance would have it's own data and that data would persist on that machine. `%LOCALAPPDATA%` at the very least is predictable.

As someone who's interested in using Electron in a large enterprise environment with roaming profiles, I very much would prefer `%LOCALAPPDATA%` be the default. `%APPDATA%` is defaulted to far too often, and isn't particularly friendly to the poor AD infrastructure guys.

Just because something _can_ be done and _is commonly_ done doesn't mean it's the best or right thing to do. For instance we have a small percentage of our workforce who are remote workers, as such they very sensitive to network bandwidth and latency. Having the default behavior be one that has even the potential for a negative experience without a compelling reason is laying the groundwork for poor user experience. Especially when the ability to revert to that behavior can be restored on an _opt-in_ basis.

I think @etiktin has the right idea, not that I'm anything but another face from The Internet voicing an opinion.

> I'm very much not excited about this change - I don't care at all that what we're doing now is technically wrong, and while I have some sympathy for the roaming profiles scenario, I don't think it warrants breaking software to do it.

The beauty of this is that you have time to plan and prepare for it, which in this instance _(taking an educated guess)_ should be as simple as a call to `app.setPath()`. After reading through, I'm having a hard time seeing any solid reasons against this change.

With a deprecation plan, built-in checking on startup from Electron itself, and the ability to opt-in to whatever behavior is needed should cover all use cases with sane OS-specific defaults. Exactly what I'd want to see from a platform for cross-platform development. And without breaking any current apps, to boot!

If individual apps want to choose to put this in a different place they totally can via `app.setPath`, I don't think we need any more discussion on this, we're probably going to keep it as-is to align with what Google Chrome does

@paulcbetts
As [told previously](https://github.com/atom/electron/issues/1404#issuecomment-93660267), Electron has currently not the same behavior than Google Chrome. Google Chrome store user data in %LOCALAPPDATA% which is not roamed.

Aligning with Google Chrome would mean changing Electron Behavior.

Here a summary of for/against changing for %LOCALAPPDATA%:
**For:**
- This is the recommended & good way to store user data
- Prevent unexpected roaming of data (may cause issues for app developers and system admin)
- This is what Google Chrome do

**Against:**
- This is a change. Could be breaking
- May conflict with Squirrel install path

We could stat to keep the current behavior and close this topic but in this case, I think we should add a notice in the documentation about it, because this is not the expected behavior and it can cause issues.
It will be great as an option for the developers and we will able to choose between %appdata% and %localappdata%.

> It will be great as an option for the developers and we will able to choose between %appdata% and %localappdata%.

This thread is confusing people already - this is _already_ an option in Electron today. The proposal is to change the default behavior

After #2668 getting fixed, there is no bug preventing developers from using `app.setPath` to use `%localappdata%`. I'm closing this since this is a breaking change and not everyone likes it, and it is very easy to opt out of this.

My windows home directory at work has a 1 GB restriction. Using Electron apps not changing this default behaviour may cause my machine to permanently remind me about deleting some files to get back below the 1 GB restriction.

Changing the default behaviour of Electron means, solving this issue proactive. Even if the reasons are bad programming practices by someone else. The more Electron apps there will be, the more often users will run into this mess.

> My windows home directory at work has a 1 GB restriction.

Both `%APPDATA%` and `%LOCALAPPDATA%` are in your home directory?  I don't think there is anywhere else we can put these files if we wanted to.

Also you'll find that most of the space being consumed will be due to the apps using `Squirrel.Windows` which installs applications into `%LOCALAPPDATA%`.

IMO your use case is super rare and there isn't really anything as a framework we can do about it, these files have to go somewhere in your home directory by default as it is the only place we can guarantee you have write access to.  It should be up to the app to let you choose a new location for these files and use the APIs Electron provides.
But only Roaming gets synced here. Although I'm not sure how other companies handle that.
